paragraphs.name: 7fe4
paragraphs.text: The Designer as Health Practitioner
from ‘Design for Human and Planetary Health’ D.C. Wahl 2006

paragraphs.name: 05db
paragraphs.text: The challenge is to manage the relationships between human activities and the physical, biological, social and economic environments in a way that protects and promotes health but at the same time does not threaten the integrity of the natural systems on which the physical and biological systems depend. This includes maintaining the availability of environmental resources, the functioning of natural systems that receive wastes produced by human society, and a stable climate.

paragraphs.name: 88f0
paragraphs.text: — Valerie Brown et al., 2005, p.45

paragraphs.name: 6aac
paragraphs.text: Preventive health care at the whole systems level starts with design. As active participants of a complex dynamic system through which everything is fundamentally interconnected, we cannot but affect — to greater or lesser extent — the future of this process as a whole. Thus all our actions do to some extent affect how the system will be in the future.

paragraphs.name: 7df0
paragraphs.text: We are ‘designers’ of our specie’s and the planet’s future, whether through conscious choice, awareness of the context of our actions, and carefully considered intention, or through a mode of participation that is so conceptually detached from our creative involvement in the overall process that it makes us oblivious to the profound obligation to participate appropriately and co-create responsibly.

paragraphs.name: b885
paragraphs.text: Based on the work of McMichael (2001), Valerie Brown and her colleagues list two criteria that should guide human behaviour if we hope to avoid serious damage to the biosphere and the natural processes that maintain its health. The first strategy is “to consume nature’s flows while conserving the stocks (that is, live off the ‘interest’ while conserving natural capital.” The second strategy is “to increase society’s stocks (human resources, civil institutions) and limit the flow of material and energy” (Brown et al., 2005, p.45).

paragraphs.name: ddeb
paragraphs.text: These strategies, aimed at maintaining both human and ecological health, clearly focus on preserving and where possible increasing natural and social capital — an underlying theme that runs through many of the design approaches discussed in this thesis. To turn these salutogenic prescriptions and intentions into reality requires an eco-literate and actively participating citizenry.

paragraphs.name: a088
paragraphs.text: Maintaining and improving systemic health across all of nature’s fundamentally scale- linked processes requires an intentionally salutogenic attitude to be widely spread throughout society. The global shift towards improved health and sustainability involves everyone, everywhere. To achieve the attainable utopia of sustainable communities and cultures, not only professional designers but everybody needs to act consciously, responsibly, and with intention to design and create such a sustainable future through the daily actions and the relationships we form in our human communities as wel as with the wider community of life.

paragraphs.name: e8ea
paragraphs.text: The holistic perspective on sustainability recognizes that the fundamental goal guiding us in the uncertain and uncontrollable journey towards a sustainable future should be to improve the overall health of the whole system. Through a deeper understanding of the relationship between eco-systemic, biospheric, and human health, a new integrative principle for a holistic approach to sustainability is emerging — the preservation of health.

paragraphs.name: 6f22
paragraphs.text: If all our actions are considered in the light of how they might affect the health of the local and the global environment as well as the health of human communities and individuals, both in the short- and in the long-term, appropriate participation and thus sustainability will cease to be an elusive concept and become a tangible reality.

paragraphs.name: e65f
paragraphs.text: Truly everybody is a designer, whether professionally engaged in what has conventionally been considered as the design industry or whether simply contributing to cultural and societal evolution through the way we relate to nature and culture and express these attitudes through our actions.

paragraphs.name: bb32
paragraphs.text: Not only is everybody a designer, but all designers are health practitioners. In a society where the focus shifts from the treatment of disease to the prevention of disease by increasing positive health, whether personal, community or planetary, everybody becomes a health practitioner.

paragraphs.name: bdde
paragraphs.text: Much of the shift towards sustainability has to do with assuming personal responsibility, based on a socially and ecologically literate understanding. Individuals and communities are clearly benefiting from not deferring the responsibility for individual health to a state health system or private doctors, but assuming personal health responsibility through living a healthy life-style that includes physical exercise, a healthy diet and emotionally and spiritually nourishing relationships to our communities and nature.

In the same way, it is time to stop refering the responsibility for planetary health to government institutions, large businesses and policy makers, and assume personal responsibility for the way that our everyday actions affect the health of not only ourselves and our local community, but also of local ecosystems and the planet. The effective use of life-long education, responsible marketing, and a creation of more responsible product and lifestyle choices will facilitate a rapid spread of such salutogenic values throughout the world. This will create system wide synergistic benefits.

paragraphs.name: cbc1
paragraphs.text: Planetary and human health is fundamentaly interconnected and interdependent. There are no actions that do not affect health as the pattern that connects. Salutogenic decision-making and design is a priority for long-term survival and sustainability. In this context, everybody can be understood as a designer and all designers are health practitioners.

paragraphs.name: 942b
paragraphs.text: In this chapter I have tried to review a number of already existing initiatives and approaches that are promoting salutogenic design at different scales of the holarchy, from individual to community health, on to healthy societies and ecosystem health management. All these approaches are increasing the overall resilience and health of the planetary biosphere containing nature and culture. I have tried to highlight the importance of the work of Antonovsky, Wilkinson, Brown and Waltner-Toews in the context of conceptualising as well as practically engaging in a salutogenic and scale -linking design approach.

Furthermore, I introduced a variety of design practitioners and educators in the field of ecological and sustainable design as operating from a fundamentally salutogenic intention (e.g. McHarg, Todd & Jack-Todd, Orr, Van der Ryn &Cowan, McDonough & Braungart). The basic strategy that helps to turn such a salutogenic intention into creative practice is to meet human needs in ways that integrate appropriately and sustainably into natural process. To do so, designers have to be ecologically and socially literate. In particular, they have to aim to better understand natural process in its complexity, while acknowledging our limits of prediction and control of natural processes.

paragraphs.name: 40bf
paragraphs.text: Seen from a holistic and integrative perspective, sustainable design has to be informed by nature in order to appropriately integrate into nature in such a way that it contributes to positive health across all scales of the natural holarchy. The next chapter will explore the historical roots and the emergence of ecological, salutogenic, and scale-linking design. I will refer to this emerging movement of global change toward increased sustainability through appropriate local adaptation by design as the ‘natural design movement. Waltner-Toews concludes his insightful and instructive book on Ecosystem Sustainability and Health with a lucid assessment of the problematique of human and planetary health and our role as co- designers of our own future.

paragraphs.name: 856c
paragraphs.text: This process never ends. The universe unfolds and changes, often (usually?) in surprising ways. Therefore, the process of ecosystem health management must become a process whereby we learn from our experience and respond and adapt to the unexpected, reassessing complaints, rethinking the shapes of the ultimate patients, testing different responses. We need good indicators of sustainability and health that not only reflect our best scientific understanding of what is necessary to survive, but also our deepest intuitive sense of what is good and important to survive well. … There is an underlying assumption … Ecosystem approaches to health requires that — with all our faults and betrayals and stupidity and brilliance and humility — we need somehow to trust each other. We do not seek blind trust. Nor do we need to trust each other about everything. We know each other too well for that anyway. We need to trust each other to deal honourably in our public spaces — in the water, the air, the landscape, the way a bird trusts that the branch it lands on will not break, or a fish trusts that water will provide it with oxygen. This is the kind of democratic trust, where we share responsibilities, rights, knowledge and activities, but where we also put into place ‘quality control’ rules, so we can check up on each other. We have responsibilities not just to work collectively and think systemically, but to be sceptical of everything we do, even as we trust. This is not an easy road, but one, I would think, well worth taking. Even if the world ends — which it will someday in any case — we still want to be able to hold our heads up high with dignity as a species, and be able to say we have lived not only long, but well (Waltner-Toews, 2004, p.128).

[This is the introduction to my 2006 PhD Thesis in ‘Design for Human and Planetary Health: A Holistic/Integral Approach to Complexity and Sustainability’. This research and 10 years of experience as an educator, consultant, activist, and expert in whole systems design and transformative innovation have led me to publish Designing Regenerative Cultures in May 2016.]
